data.title: Famous black animators
data.meta_description: Hi. I would like to know how many famous animators are black/African-American? I recall reading and seeing an article about that in Essence Magazine...
data.text:
Floyd Norman is a former Disney animator whose credits stretch as long as my arm, and may be the only black animator who worked with Walt directly. This is not meant as a negative towards Disney, mind you -- he came from a different era.

James Tucker of Justice League, Legion of Superheroes, and the upcoming Batman: The Brave & the Bold is also black. I'm sure that there was one other JL staffer who was black (and wasn't Dwayne McDuffie, who's a writer and not an animator), but I'm blanking on a name at the moment.

-- Ed

I don't how how famous these people are but there's Ron Husband:

http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-3990932.html

There's people listed here:

http://blackcartoons.tripod.com/

and

I just found this:

from http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-3990932.html :

There have been very few women of color in animation history. The first woman (of any color) that I know of who worked in the US industry was Lillian Friedman at Fleischers in 1933. Myron Waldman helped move her up when Al Eugster, Grim Natwick, Berny Wolf and Shamus Culhane all jumped ship to Hollywood and Iwerks.

While she wasn't an animator, Mary Tebb was a crucial part of the Iwerks Studio color department and had a leadership role there. Unfortunately her role didn't help women in other positions there. Dot Powers, the daughter of mogul, Pat Powers, languished in minor roles at the Iwerks Studio. She told me that she attempted to get promoted to animator many times and believed she had the skill to do so but was always kept out of the boys club. Her father would not intervene on her behalf and she eventually left the industry somewhat bitter about the entire experience.

And of course, lest our US-big studio fetish prevent us from looking beyond our shores, Lotte Reininger was already renowned in the 1920s for her silhouette animation.

Sorry for restarting this thread, but a month ago, I was talking about this subject over a couple weeks ago.

To me, they're all famous.

James Tucker (Animator on Animaniacs for Startoons; Character Designer/Director on Superman:TAS, Batman Beyond; Producer on Justice League, Legion of Superheroes, and Batman: The Brave and The Bold)

David Teague (Director on The Oz Kids, Sabrina: TAS, Extreme Ghostbusters)

Frank C. Braxton (The first noted African-American animator working under Ben Washam in the Chuck Jones unit at Warner Bros. Cartoons; directed The Bullwinkle Show and George of the Jungle)

Floyd Norman (The first African-American animator at Disney who did animation on The Jungle Book, 101 Dalmations, Written for Hanna-Barbera; Mickey Mouse comics)

Byron Vaughns (Storyboard Artist/Director on Tiny Toons and Animaniacs; Producer/Director on Dumb and Dumber: TAS for Hanna-Barbera, The Pink Panther Show, and The Lionhearts for MGM)

Barry Caldwell (Writer, storyboard artist, and director on Tiny Toons and Animaniacs)

Lenord Robinson (Storyboard Artist/Director on Taz-Mania, Animaniacs, The Sylvester and Tweety Mysteries, and The Proud Family; Producer on Waynehead)

Carlos Baeza (Director on The Simpsons)

T.J. House (Animator on Animaniacs; Director on The Proud Family and Tom and Jerry Tales; storyboard artist on Happiness is A Warm Blanket, Charlie Brown)

Bob McKnight (Animator on Sesame Street segments; Character Designer on Mickey, Donald and Goofy in The Three Musketeers and The Looney Tunes Show)

Dan Haskett (Master Animator/Character Designer on The Little Mermaid, Beauty and the Beast, Tiny Toons, Animaniacs, Toy Story, and many more projects)

Maurice "Pixote" Hunt (Character Designer on The Snorks; Directed The Pagemaster; Director on Fantasia 2000 and One by One)

Bruce W. Smith (Directed Bebe's Kids, Created The Proud Family and Da Boom Crew; co-directed Space Jam)

Rodney Clouden (Storyboard Artist on Futurama; Director on American Dad!)

Ron Myrick (Director on Sonic The Hegdehog, The Addams Family; Producer at Saban, DiC, and WB Animation)

Dennis Woodyard (Director on Gargoyles; NASCAR Racers)

Milton Knight (Director on The Twisted Tales of Felix the Cat; Storyboarded an episode of Johnny Test; designed Sonic The Hedgehog; worked on Cool World)

Edward Bell (Layout artist on Ren & Sitmpy; director on HBO's Happily Every After)

Anthony Bell (Director on HBO's Happily Ever After, Duckman. The Wild Thornberrys, Rugrats, All Grown Up!, and Alpha and Omega)

LeSean Thomas (Co-Director on The Boondocks; Storyboard artist on The Legend of Korra; Producer/Director on the upcoming Black Dynamite series)

Kenny Thompkins (Character Designer on Tale Spin and Chip n' Dale: Rescue Rangers; Director on Jungle Cubs)

Louis Scarborugh Jr. (Animator on Raggedy Ann and Andy; Storyboarding The Addams Family, The Smurfs, etc.)

Joe Horne (Director on Jungle Cubs, Timon and Pumbaa, Class of 3000 (also Producer), The Boondocks, The Oblongs, Teamo Supremo, The Baby Huey Show, and Liquid Television)

Ron Husband (Animator at Disney)

Larry Houston (Director/Producer on X-Men, The Real Adventures of Jonny Quest , The Karate Kid, and Care Bears: Adventures In Care-A-Lot)

Jim Simon (started the first African American animation studio, Wantu Animation; worked on Sesame Street)

Phil Mendez (Created Foofur and Kissyfur; directed Tom Sawyer at MGM)

Swinton O Scott III (Director on The Simpsons, Family Guy, Futurama, God, the Devil and Bob, What's New Scooby Doo?, and The Looney Tunes Show; Producer on Static Shock)
